review.title: Towards an ASP-Based Architecture for Autonomous UAVs in Dynamic Environments (Extended Abstract)
review.abstract: Traditional AI reasoning techniques have been used successfully in many domains, including logistics, scheduling and game playing. This paper is part of a project aimed at investigating how such techniques can be extended to coordinate teams of unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) in dynamic environments. Specifically challenging are real-world environments where UAVs and other network-enabled devices must communicate to coordinate -- and communication actions are neither reliable nor free. Such network-centric environments are common in military, public safety and commercial applications, yet most research (even multi-agent planning) usually takes communications among distributed agents as a given. We address this challenge by developing an agent architecture and reasoning algorithms based on Answer Set Programming (ASP). Although ASP has been used successfully in a number of applications, to the best of our knowledge this is the first practical application of a complete ASP-based agent architecture. It is also the first practical application of ASP involving a combination of centralized reasoning, decentralized reasoning, execution monitoring, and reasoning about network communications.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: Unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) promise to revolutionize the way we use our airspace, from talking about automating navigation for large shipping companies to using small helicopters as "suppliers" to drop your packages at your door, it is clear that our airspace will become increasingly crowded in the near future. This increased utilization and congestion has created the need for new and other ways to coordinate assets that use airspace. Currently, airspace management is the job of most human controllers. As the number of units that use airspace increases enormously - many of which are autonomous - the need for improved autonomy techniques becomes evident. The challenge in an environment full of UAVs is that the world is highly dynamic and the communication environment is uncertain, making coordination more difficult. Communication actions in such an environment are neither reliable nor cost-free.The work being discussed here is in the context of developing a novel application of network-aware AV to the problem of intelligent reasoning and reasoning.

sections.heading: 2 Related Work
sections.text: The integration of network characteristics into planning and decision-making was investigated in (Usbeck et al. 2012), but the results of the authors suggest that the effectiveness and performance of plan execution is increased with increased network awareness during the planning phase. UAV coordination approach in this current work combines network awareness during the reasoning process with a plan-conscious network layer. (In our work, we do not separate planning from the engagement of under-used UAVs and do not rely on ad-hoc, hard-wired behaviors. Our approach gives the planner more flexibility and finer control over the actions that occur in the plans and that allow for revisions to occur.) The UAV coordination approach in this current work combines network awareness during the reasoning process with a plan-conscious network layer.

sections.heading: 3 Motivating Scenario
sections.text: In order to underline the need for networking and networking, it is necessary for UAVs to be able to capture images of three objectives; the simplest solution to this problem is to neglect the scope of the individual objectives, in the form of a plan linking the individual objectives.

sections.heading: 4 Technical Approach
sections.text: In this section we describe the problem in more detail, discuss the design of the agent architecture and the thought modules, and demonstrate the sophistication of the resulting behavior of the agents in two scenarios. We start from a familiarity with ASP and refer the reader (Gelfond and Lifschitz 1991; Niemela and Simons 2000; Baral 2003) for an introduction to this topic.

sections.heading: 4.1 Problem Formulation
sections.text: A problem instance for coordinating drones to observe targets and transmit information (e.g. images) to a home base is defined by a set of drones, u1, u2,.., a set of targets, t1, t2,.., a (possibly empty) set of fixed radio relays, r1, r2,.. and a home base. The drones, relays, and home base are referred to as radio nodes (or network nodes). Two nodes are in radio contact when they are at a distance from each other, called radio range1, or when they can relay information to each other through intermediate radio nodes that are within radio range themselves. The drones will travel from home base to the targets to photograph the targets and transmit them to home base. A drone will automatically take an image when it reaches a target.

sections.heading: 4.3 Network-Aware Reasoning
sections.text: The most important reasoning tasks (centralized mission planning, as well as anomalous detection, explanation and planning within each action step) are reduced to finding models of formalizations of the corresponding problems based on answers. Central to all reasoning tasks is the ability to represent the evolution of the environment over time. Such a development is designed into a transition diagram (Gelfond and Lifschitz 1993), a diagram whose nodes correspond to the states of the environment, and whose arcs describe state transitions based on the execution of actions. Let F be a collection of flows, expressions representing relevant properties of the domain that may change over time, and let A be a collection of actions. A fluid letter l is a flow f or its negation f. A state that is a complete and consistent set of fluent words.The transition diagram is formalized in ASP by rules that describe the direct effects of actions, and their indicators.

sections.heading: 5 Conclusion and Future Work
sections.text: This paper discussed a novel application of an ASP-based intelligent agent architecture to the problem of UAV coordination taking into account network communication. Our work demonstrates the benefits of such network-aware reasoning. In ongoing experimental evaluations, our approach led to a reduction of mission duration by up to 30% and total time between 50% and 100%. We expect the benefit of a realistic networking model to become even more apparent in more complex scenarios.
